verses.verse: (Prov. 19:12; 1 Pet. 5:8) Like a roaring lion and a charging bear (Ex. 1:14; Prov. 29:2; Matt. 2:16) Is a wicked ruler over poor people.
A ruler who lacks understanding is a great (Eccl. 10:16; Is. 3:12) oppressor, But he who hates covetousness will prolong his days.
(Gen. 9:6) A man burdened with bloodshed will flee into a pit; Let no one help him.
Whoever walks blamelessly will be saved, But he who is perverse in his ways will suddenly fall.
(Prov. 12:11; 20:13) He who tills his land will have plenty of bread, But he who follows frivolity will have poverty enough!
A faithful man will abound with blessings, (Prov. 13:11; 20:21; 23:4; 1 Tim. 6:9) But he who hastens to be rich will not go unpunished.
(Prov. 18:5) To show partiality is not good, (Ezek. 13:19) Because for a piece of bread a man will transgress.
A man with an evil eye hastens after riches, And does not consider that (Prov. 21:5) poverty will come upon him.
(Prov. 27:5, 6) He who rebukes a man will find more favor afterward Than he who flatters with the tongue.
Whoever robs his father or his mother, And says, “It is no transgression,” The same (Prov. 18:9) is companion to a destroyer.
(Prov. 13:10) He who is of a proud heart stirs up strife, (Prov. 29:25; 1 Tim. 6:6) But he who trusts in the LORD will be prospered.
He who (Prov. 3:5) trusts in his own heart is a fool, But whoever walks wisely will be delivered.
(Deut. 15:7; Prov. 19:17; 22:9) He who gives to the poor will not lack, But he who hides his eyes will have many curses.
When the wicked arise, (Job 24:4) men hide themselves; But when they perish, the righteous increase.
He (2 Chr. 36:16; Prov. 6:15) who is often rebuked, and hardens his neck, Will suddenly be destroyed, and that without remedy.
When the righteous are in authority, the (Esth. 8:15; Prov. 28:12) people rejoice; But when a wicked man rules, (Esth. 4:3) the people groan.
Whoever loves wisdom makes his father rejoice, But a companion of harlots wastes his wealth.
The king establishes the land by justice, But he who receives bribes overthrows it.
A man who (Prov. 26:28) flatters his neighbor Spreads a net for his feet.
By transgression an evil man is snared, But the righteous sings and rejoices.
The righteous (Job 29:16; Ps. 41:1; Prov. 31:8, 9) considers the cause of the poor, But the wicked does not understand such knowledge.
Scoffers (Prov. 11:11) set a city aflame, But wise men turn away wrath.
If a wise man contends with a foolish man, (Matt. 11:17) Whether the fool rages or laughs, there is no peace.
(Gen. 4:5-8; 1 John 3:12) The bloodthirsty hate the blameless, But the upright seek his well-being.
A fool vents all his (Prov. 14:33) feelings, But a wise man holds them back.
If a ruler pays attention to lies, All his servants become wicked.
The poor man and the oppressor have this in common: ((Matt. 5:45)) The LORD gives light to the eyes of both.
